perturbation.original_text: 1.7      "Defect" shall mean any failure of Licensed Technology to meet the Specification as a result of a material failure (including an error or "bug" that is material) of the Licensed Technology. "Material" is defined as priority A, B, and C in Article 6.3.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.7      "Defect" shall mean any failure of Licensed Technology to meet the Specification. The classification of defects is outlined elsewhere in this agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the explicit reference to Article 6.3 for the definition of 'Material' defects (priorities A, B, and C), the contract creates uncertainty. Other sections, specifically Article 6, still rely on the understanding that defects are categorized in this manner. This omission contradicts the continued use of those categories and makes enforcement unclear.

perturbation.original_text: A runtime license fee shall be paid for each SRM in the Licensee Product (Exhibit B) which contains the Licensed Technology for Basic Services and simple conferencing which does not require network echo cancellation technology (Exhibit A) sold by LICENSEE. Licensee Products which do not run the Licensed Technology are not subject to runtime license fees.
perturbation.changed_text: A license fee shall be paid for each SRM in the Licensee Product (Exhibit B) sold by LICENSEE. All Licensee Products are subject to license fees.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'which contains the Licensed Technology for Basic Services and simple conferencing which does not require network echo cancellation technology' creates a contradiction. Previously, Licensee Products *without* the defined Licensed Technology were exempt, the modified text creates a blanket fee, regardless of whether the licensed technology is utilized.

perturbation.original_text: 2.       LICENSEE's Customer shall have the right to reproduce the Licensed Technology for distribution and make a reasonable number of copies of the Licensed Technology for backup or archival purposes.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.       LICENSEE's Customer shall have the right to reproduce the Licensed Technology for distribution.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'and make a reasonable number of copies of the Licensed Technology for backup or archival purposes' creates a contradiction. Without these details on what is considered a 'fair' or 'authorized' use, the contract remains unclear. Especially if the 'licensed technology' fails. How will the client recover a previous authorized version if the 'copies' clause has been removed?
